TITLE: 外層通用數據結構JSON示例
DESCRIPTION: 展示了Bybit API的通用JSON響應結構，包含狀態碼、消息、結果數據、額外信息和時間戳等字段。
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/i18n/zh-TW/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/v5/guide.mdx#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
```
{
    "retCode": 0,
    "retMsg": "OK",
    "result": {
    },
    "retExtInfo": {},
    "time": 1671017382656
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Creating an Order with Bybit API
DESCRIPTION: HTTP POST endpoint for creating orders across Bybit's trading products. This endpoint supports Spot, Margin trading, USDT perpetual, USDT futures, USDC perpetual, USDC futures, Inverse Futures and Options.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/order/create-order.mdx#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: HTTP
CODE:
```
POST /v5/order/create
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Submitting Spot and Linear Orders Using HTTP API v5 POST Request
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to create various types of orders on Bybit using a raw HTTP POST request to the /v5/order/create endpoint. It requires authentication headers including an API key, signature, timestamp, and recv window. The JSON payload defines different order parameters such as category (spot or linear), symbol, side (buy/sell), orderType (limit/market), quantity, price, timeInForce options, and advanced features like takeProfit, stopLoss, and leverage flags. It supports multiple order variants like post-only, TP/SL attached orders, and margin usage. The input is a JSON body describing the order details, with the output being an order execution response.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/order/create-order.mdx#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: http
CODE:
```
POST /v5/order/create HTTP/1.1
Host: api-testnet.bybit.com
X-BAPI-SIGN: XXXXX
X-BAPI-API-KEY: xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
X-BAPI-TIMESTAMP: 1672211928338
X-BAPI-RECV-WINDOW: 5000
Content-Type: application/json

// Spot Limit order with market tp sl
{"category": "spot","symbol": "BTCUSDT","side": "Buy","orderType": "Limit","qty": "0.01","price": "28000","timeInForce": "PostOnly","takeProfit": "35000","stopLoss": "27000","tpOrderType": "Market","slOrderType": "Market"}

// Spot Limit order with limit tp sl
{"category": "spot","symbol": "BTCUSDT","side": "Buy","orderType": "Limit","qty": "0.01","price": "28000","timeInForce": "PostOnly","takeProfit": "35000","stopLoss": "27000","tpLimitPrice": "36000","slLimitPrice": "27500","tpOrderType": "Limit","slOrderType": "Limit"}

// Spot PostOnly normal order
{"category":"spot","symbol":"BTCUSDT","side":"Buy","orderType":"Limit","qty":"0.1","price":"15600","timeInForce":"PostOnly","orderLinkId":"spot-test-01","isLeverage":0,"orderFilter":"Order"}

// Spot TP/SL order
{"category":"spot","symbol":"BTCUSDT","side":"Buy","orderType":"Limit","qty":"0.1","price":"15600","triggerPrice": "15000", "timeInForce":"Limit","orderLinkId":"spot-test-02","isLeverage":0,"orderFilter":"tpslOrder"}

// Spot margin normal order (UTA)
{"category":"spot","symbol":"BTCUSDT","side":"Buy","orderType":"Limit","qty":"0.1","price":"15600","timeInForce":"GTC","orderLinkId":"spot-test-limit","isLeverage":1,"orderFilter":"Order"}

// Spot Market Buy order, qty is quote currency
{"category":"spot","symbol":"BTCUSDT","side":"Buy","orderType":"Market","qty":"200","timeInForce":"IOC","orderLinkId":"spot-test-04","isLeverage":0,"orderFilter":"Order"}


// USDT Perp open long position (one-way mode)
{"category":"linear","symbol":"BTCUSDT","side":"Buy","orderType":"Limit","qty":"1","price":"25000","timeInForce":"GTC","positionIdx":0,"orderLinkId":"usdt-test-01","reduceOnly":false,"takeProfit":"28000","stopLoss":"20000","tpslMode":"Partial","tpOrderType":"Limit","slOrderType":"Limit","tpLimitPrice":"27500","slLimitPrice":"20500"}

// USDT Perp close long position (one-way mode)
{"category": "linear", "symbol": "BTCUSDT", "side": "Sell", "orderType": "Limit", "qty": "1", "price": "30000", "timeInForce": "GTC", "positionIdx": 0, "orderLinkId": "usdt-test-02", "reduceOnly": true}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Canceling Withdrawal Using Bybit Unified Trading HTTP Client - Python
DESCRIPTION: This snippet uses the pybit unified_trading library to programmatically cancel a withdrawal. It initiates a session using provided API key and secret, then calls the cancel_withdrawal method with the specific withdrawal ID. Requires installation of pybit, valid API credentials, and optional testnet selection; returns the API response containing withdrawal cancellation status.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/asset/withdraw/cancel-withdraw.mdx#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from pybit.unified_trading import HTTP
session = HTTP(
    testnet=True,
    api_key="xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx",
    api_secret="xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx",
)
print(session.cancel_withdrawal(
    id="10197",
))
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Submitting Batch Orders using HTTP Request
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to structure an HTTP POST request to the Bybit API '/v5/order/create-batch' endpoint for placing multiple orders in a single request. It includes necessary headers such as API key, signature, timestamp, and content type. The JSON payload specifies the category (e.g., spot) and an array of individual orders with attributes like symbol, side, order type, quantity, price, and time-in-force. This example requires prior setup of API credentials and signature generation. The expected input includes order parameters for each trade; the output is the HTTP response confirming batch order status.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/order/batch-place.mdx#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: http
CODE:
```
POST /v5/order/create-batch HTTP/1.1
Host: api-testnet.bybit.com
X-BAPI-SIGN: XXXXX
X-BAPI-API-KEY: xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
X-BAPI-TIMESTAMP: 1672222064519
X-BAPI-RECV-WINDOW: 5000
Content-Type: application/json

{
    "category": "spot",
    "request": [
        {
            "symbol": "BTCUSDT",
            "side": "Buy",
            "orderType": "Limit",
            "isLeverage": 0,
            "qty": "0.05",
            "price": "30000",
            "timeInForce": "GTC",
            "orderLinkId": "spot-btc-03"
        },
        {
            "symbol": "ATOMUSDT",
            "side": "Sell",
            "orderType": "Limit",
            "isLeverage": 0,
            "qty": "2",
            "price": "12",
            "timeInForce": "GTC",
            "orderLinkId": "spot-atom-03"
        }
    ]
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Confirming a Quote Using Bybit Node.js SDK
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to confirm a quote using the Bybit JavaScript SDK (RestClientV5). The client is configured for testnet with API key and secret. The method "confirmConvertQuote" is called asynchronously with the required "quoteTxId" parameter, returning a promise. Response and error handling is performed via .then() and .catch() respectively. This snippet requires the "bybit-api" Node.js package and valid API credentials.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/asset/convert/confirm-quote.mdx#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
const { RestClientV5 } = require('bybit-api');

const client = new RestClientV5({
  testnet: true,
  key: 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx',
  secret: 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx',
});

client
  .confirmConvertQuote({
    quoteTxId: '10100108106409343501030232064',
  })
  .then((response) => {
    console.log(response);
  })
  .catch((error) => {
    console.error(error);
  });
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Batch Cancelling Orders using Bybit Node.js Client
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use the `bybit-api` Node.js client for batch order cancellation. It involves initializing the `RestClientV5` with credentials and calling the `batchCancelOrders` method with the category and an array of objects specifying the symbol and order identifier.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/order/batch-cancel.mdx#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: n4js
CODE:
```
const { RestClientV5 } = require('bybit-api');

const client = new RestClientV5({
    testnet: true,
    key: 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx',
    secret: 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx',
});

client
    .batchCancelOrders('spot', [
        {
            "symbol": "BTCUSDT",
            "orderId": "1666800494330512128"
        },
        {
            "symbol": "ATOMUSDT",
            "orderLinkId": "1666800494330512129"
        },
    ])
    .then((response) => {
        console.log(response);
    })
    .catch((error) => {
        console.error(error);
    });
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Parsing Bybit Batch Order JSON Response
DESCRIPTION: Provides a sample JSON response representing the result of a successful batch order placement request to Bybit API. The response includes return code and message, an array of order objects with attributes such as category, symbol, order IDs, link IDs, and creation timestamps. It also contains extended info listing codes and messages for each individual order and a server timestamp. This example shows the expected successful structure returned upon batch order creation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/order/batch-place.mdx#_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
```
{
    "retCode": 0,
    "retMsg": "OK",
    "result": {
        "list": [
            {
                "category": "spot",
                "symbol": "BTCUSDT",
                "orderId": "1666800494330512128",
                "orderLinkId": "spot-btc-03",
                "createAt": "1713434102752"
            },
            {
                "category": "spot",
                "symbol": "ATOMUSDT",
                "orderId": "1666800494330512129",
                "orderLinkId": "spot-atom-03",
                "createAt": "1713434102752"
            }
        ]
    },
    "retExtInfo": {
        "list": [
            {
                "code": 0,
                "msg": "OK"
            },
            {
                "code": 0,
                "msg": "OK"
            }
        ]
    },
    "time": 1713434102753
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Querying Open/Closed Orders (Python)
DESCRIPTION: This Python code uses the `pybit` library to query open or closed orders from the Bybit exchange.  It initializes an HTTP session with API credentials and calls the `get_open_orders` method with specified parameters.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/order/open-order.mdx#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from pybit.unified_trading import HTTP
session = HTTP(
    testnet=True,
    api_key="xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx",
    api_secret="xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx",
)
print(session.get_open_orders(
    category="linear",
    symbol="ETHUSDT",
    openOnly=0,
    limit=1,
))
```

TITLE: Updating Order Creation API
DESCRIPTION: The `create-order` API has been updated to include `takeProfit`, `stopLoss`, `tpLimitPrice`, `slLimitPrice`, `tpOrderType`, and `slOrderType` parameters for setting take profit and stop loss on limit orders in unified account spot trading.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/i18n/zh-TW/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/changelog/v5.mdx#_snippet_59

LANGUAGE: REST
CODE:
```
N/A
```

TITLE: Querying Instrument Info using Java
DESCRIPTION: This snippet retrieves instrument information using the Bybit API Java SDK.  It creates an asynchronous market data REST client, builds a `MarketDataRequest` with category, symbol, and other optional parameters, and then calls `getInstrumentsInfo` to fetch the data asynchronously. The result is printed to the console.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/market/instrument.mdx#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: java
CODE:
```
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.CategoryType;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.market.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.market.request.MarketDataRequest;
import com.bybit.api.client.service.BybitApiClientFactory;
var client = BybitApiClientFactory.newInstance().newAsyncMarketDataRestClient();
var instrumentInfoRequest = MarketDataRequest.builder().category(CategoryType.LINEAR).symbol("BTCUSDT").instrumentStatus(InstrumentStatus.TRADING).limit(500).build();
client.getInstrumentsInfo(instrumentInfoRequest,System.out::println);
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Querying Spot Asset Info via Bybit API - HTTP
DESCRIPTION: Sends a GET request to the /v5/asset/transfer/query-asset-info endpoint to retrieve Spot asset and account status information for a specified account type and optional coin. Requires authentication headers: X-BAPI-SIGN, X-BAPI-API-KEY, X-BAPI-TIMESTAMP, and X-BAPI-RECV-WINDOW. Inputs include accountType (e.g., 'SPOT') and optional coin (e.g., 'ETH'). Outputs a JSON response with account status and asset balances. Ensure that the proper API key, signature, and timestamp are included for authentication.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/asset/balance/asset-info.mdx#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: http
CODE:
```
GET /v5/asset/transfer/query-asset-info?accountType=SPOT&coin=ETH HTTP/1.1
Host: api-testnet.bybit.com
X-BAPI-SIGN: XXXXX
X-BAPI-API-KEY: xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
X-BAPI-TIMESTAMP: 1672136538042
X-BAPI-RECV-WINDOW: 5000
```

SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/api-explorer/v5/trade/create-order.api.mdx#_snippet_0

```
{"category":"linear","symbol":"ETHUSDT","isLeverage":0,"side":"Buy","orderType":"Limit","qty":"1","price":"1000","triggerPrice":null,"triggerDirection":null,"triggerBy":null,"orderFilter":null,"orderIv":null,"timeInForce":"GTC","positionIdx":0,"orderLinkId":"test-xx1","takeProfit":null,"stopLoss":null,"tpTriggerBy":null,"slTriggerBy":null,"reduceOnly":false,"closeOnTrigger":false,"smpType":null,"mmp":null,"tpslMode":null,"tpLimitPrice":null,"slLimitPrice":null,"tpOrderType":null,"slOrderType":null}

```

TITLE: Retrieving All Coin Balances using Bybit API SDK - Node.js
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to use the bybit-api Node.js SDK's RestClientV5 to retrieve coin balances for a specific account type and coin. Requires installation of the bybit-api package and setting the testnet, key, and secret in the client instantiation. The .getAllCoinsBalance() method is called with relevant arguments, returning a promise with the JSON response. Handles both successful and error responses, logging output or errors accordingly. Ensure the environment has access to valid testnet API credentials.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/asset/balance/all-balance.mdx#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: n4js
CODE:
```
const { RestClientV5 } = require('bybit-api');

const client = new RestClientV5({
  testnet: true,
  key: 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx',
  secret: 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx',
});

client
  .getAllCoinsBalance({ accountType: 'FUND', coin: 'USDC' })
  .then((response) => {
    console.log(response);
  })
  .catch((error) => {
    console.error(error);
  });
```

TITLE: Amend Order Endpoint Request Schema - JSON
DESCRIPTION: Defines the structure and parameters for the JSON request body used to amend an existing order in Bybit's v5 Trade API. This schema supports modification of multiple order fields including order quantity, price, stop loss, take profit, trigger types, and related limit prices. Required fields are 'category' (defining the product type) and 'symbol' (defining the trading pair), while either 'orderId' or 'orderLinkId' must be provided to identify the order. The schema includes enum restrictions on fields such as 'category', 'tpslMode', and trigger price types. The payload is sent as part of the HTTP POST method to the '/v5/order/amend' path. Expected response is HTTP 200 on success. Dependencies include appropriate API key and secret headers for authentication.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/api-explorer/v5/trade/amend-order.api.mdx#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
```
{
  "category": "linear",
  "symbol": "ETHUSDT",
  "orderId": null,
  "orderLinkId": null,
  "qty": null,
  "price": null,
  "orderIv": null,
  "triggerPrice": null,
  "tpslMode": null,
  "takeProfit": null,
  "stopLoss": null,
  "triggerBy": null,
  "tpTriggerBy": null,
  "slTriggerBy": null,
  "tpLimitPrice": null,
  "slLimitPrice": null
}
```

TITLE: Subscribing to Kline Stream with PyBit WebSocket in Python
DESCRIPTION: This Python code snippet demonstrates how to subscribe to the kline data stream from Bybit using the PyBit unified trading WebSocket. It uses the WebSocket class with testnet enabled and linear channel type to connect, and sets up a callback function to handle incoming messages. The subscription request specifies the interval (in minutes) and symbol for the kline data. The code runs an infinite loop with sleep to keep the connection alive and process messages asynchronously.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/websocket/public/kline.mdx#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from pybit.unified_trading import WebSocket
from time import sleep
ws = WebSocket(
    testnet=True,
    channel_type="linear",
)
def handle_message(message):
    print(message)
ws.kline_stream(
    interval=5,
    symbol="BTCUSDT",
    callback=handle_message
)
while True:
    sleep(1)
```

TITLE: Creating Option Limit Order Asynchronously Using Java SDK
DESCRIPTION: This Java example demonstrates placing an option limit order on Bybit asynchronously using the official Java SDK. It sets up the API client factory with API key and secret, and creates an asynchronous trade REST client. The order is represented as a Map of key-value pairs specifying category (option), symbol, side (buy), order type, implied volatility, quantity, price and an order link ID. The createOrder method submits the order and prints results via a system output callback. The snippet requires Bybit Java client dependencies and imports trade domain enums and classes.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/order/create-order.mdx#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: java
CODE:
```
import com.bybit.api.client.restApi.BybitApiAsyncTradeRestClient;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.ProductType;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.TradeOrderType;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.trade.PositionIdx;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.trade.Side;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.trade.TimeInForce;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.trade.TradeOrderRequest;
import com.bybit.api.client.service.BybitApiClientFactory;
import java.util.Map;
BybitApiClientFactory factory = BybitApiClientFactory.newInstance("YOUR_API_KEY", "YOUR_API_SECRET");
BybitApiAsyncTradeRestClient client = factory.newAsyncTradeRestClient();
Map<String, Object> order =Map.of(
                  "category", "option",
                  "symbol", "BTC-29DEC23-10000-P",
                  "side", "Buy",
                  "orderType", "Limit",
                  "orderIv", "0.1",
                  "qty", "0.1",
                  "price", "5",
                  "orderLinkId", "test_orderLinkId_1"
                );
client.createOrder(order, System.out::println);
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Python Implementation for Fetching Bybit Order Book Data using pybit
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to use the pybit library to request order book data from Bybit in Python. It creates an HTTP session configured for testnet and calls the get_orderbook method with category and symbol parameters. The code provides a straightforward way to integrate order book retrieval into Python applications.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/i18n/zh-TW/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/v5/market/orderbook.mdx#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: Python
CODE:
```
from pybit.unified_trading import HTTP
session = HTTP(testnet=True)
print(session.get_orderbook(
    category="linear",
    symbol="BTCUSDT",
))
```

TITLE: Amending an Order with Java in Bybit API
DESCRIPTION: Java implementation using Bybit's client library to modify an existing XRP/USDT order. This example demonstrates changing the price and quantity using the builder pattern.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/i18n/zh-TW/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/v5/order/amend-order.mdx#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: java
CODE:
```
import com.bybit.api.client.restApi.BybitApiTradeRestClient;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.trade.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.service.BybitApiClientFactory;
BybitApiClientFactory factory = BybitApiClientFactory.newInstance("YOUR_API_KEY", "YOUR_API_SECRET");
BybitApiAsyncTradeRestClient client = factory.newAsyncTradeRestClient();
var amendOrderRequest = TradeOrderRequest.builder().orderId("1523347543495541248").category(ProductType.LINEAR).symbol("XRPUSDT")
                        .price("0.5")  // setting a new price, for example
                        .qty("15")  // and a new quantity
                        .build();
var amendedOrder = client.amendOrder(amendOrderRequest);
System.out.println(amendedOrder);
```

TITLE: Generating Authentication Signature Bybit WebSocket Python
DESCRIPTION: This Python snippet demonstrates how to generate the HMAC-SHA256 signature required for Bybit WebSocket authentication. It calculates an 'expires' timestamp, creates a message string using 'GET/realtime' and the timestamp, and then generates the signature using the API secret. This signature, along with the API key and expires timestamp, is sent in the authentication request.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/websocket/wss-authentication.mdx#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: Python
CODE:
```
# based on: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/pybit/blob/master/pybit/_http_manager.py

import hmac
import json
import time
import websocket

api_key = ""
api_secret = ""

# Generate expires.
expires = int((time.time() + 1) * 1000)

# Generate signature.
signature = str(hmac.new(
    bytes(api_secret, "utf-8"),
    bytes(f"GET/realtime{expires}", "utf-8"), digestmod="sha256"
).hexdigest())

ws = websocket.WebSocketApp(
    url=url,
    ...
)

# Authenticate with API.
ws.send(
    json.dumps({
        "op": "auth",
        "args": [api_key, expires, signature]
    })
)
```

TITLE: Interpreting Rate Limit Response Headers in Bybit API - HTTP
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates example HTTP response headers provided by the Bybit API to help users track their current rate limit status. The headers include 'X-Bapi-Limit' (the maximum allowed requests for the endpoint per window), 'X-Bapi-Limit-Status' (the remaining available requests in the current window), and 'X-Bapi-Limit-Reset-Timestamp' (when the rate limit will be reset). No specific dependencies are needed, but the headers are only present on API responses. Inputs are HTTP API requests, outputs are response headers containing rate limit information. Understanding these fields is essential for building retry and throttling logic; hitting the limits may result in HTTP 429 or 403 errors.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/rate-limit.mdx#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: http
CODE:
```
▶Response Headers
Content-Type: application/json; charset=utf-8
Content-Length: 141
X-Bapi-Limit: 100
X-Bapi-Limit-Status: 99
X-Bapi-Limit-Reset-Timestamp: 1672738134824
```

TITLE: Amending Orders with Java
DESCRIPTION: This Java example demonstrates how to amend orders using the Bybit API client. It initializes the client with API key and secret, then creates a list of `TradeOrderRequest` objects specifying the symbol, quantity, price, and order link ID for each order.  It then builds a `BatchOrderRequest` with the category and list of order requests and uses the client's `createBatchOrder` method to send the request.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/order/batch-amend.mdx#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: java
CODE:
```
import com.bybit.api.client.restApi.BybitApiAsyncTradeRestClient;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.ProductType;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.TradeOrderType;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.trade.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.service.BybitApiClientFactory;
import java.util.Arrays;
BybitApiClientFactory factory = BybitApiClientFactory.newInstance("YOUR_API_KEY", "YOUR_API_SECRET");
BybitApiAsyncTradeRestClient client = factory.newAsyncTradeRestClient();
var amendOrderRequests = Arrays.asList(TradeOrderRequest.builder().symbol("BTC-10FEB23-24000-C").qty("0.1").price("5").orderLinkId("9b381bb1-401").build(),
                TradeOrderRequest.builder().symbol("BTC-10FEB23-24000-C").qty("0.1").price("5").orderLinkId("82ee86dd-001").build());
var amendBatchOrders = BatchOrderRequest.builder().category(ProductType.OPTION).request(amendOrderRequests).build();
client.createBatchOrder(amendBatchOrders, System.out::println);
```

TITLE: Submitting Batch Orders via Bybit Node.js SDK
DESCRIPTION: This snippet uses the Bybit Node.js SDK to place batch orders asynchronously against the testnet environment. After importing and instantiating the RestClientV5 with API credentials and testnet flag, the 'batchSubmitOrders' method is called with the trading category (spot) and an array of order objects detailing symbol, side, order type, quantity, price, leverage flag, time in force, and link IDs. The method returns a promise which resolves with the response or rejects with errors. This example requires Node.js environment and the 'bybit-api' npm module.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/order/batch-place.mdx#_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
const { RestClientV5 } = require('bybit-api');

const client = new RestClientV5({
    testnet: true,
    key: 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx',
    secret: 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx',
});

client
    .batchSubmitOrders('spot', [
        {
            "symbol": "BTCUSDT",
            "side": "Buy",
            "orderType": "Limit",
            "isLeverage": 0,
            "qty": "0.05",
            "price": "30000",
            "timeInForce": "GTC",
            "orderLinkId": "spot-btc-03"
        },
        {
            "symbol": "ATOMUSDT",
            "side": "Sell",
            "orderType": "Limit",
            "isLeverage": 0,
            "qty": "2",
            "price": "12",
            "timeInForce": "GTC",
            "orderLinkId": "spot-atom-03"
        },
    ])
        .then((response) => {
        console.log(response);
    })
        .catch((error) => {
        console.error(error);
    });
```

TITLE: Creating Batch Orders in Go with Bybit Client

LANGUAGE: go
CODE:
```
import (
    "context"
	"fmt"
	bybit "https://github.com/bybit-exchange/bybit.go.api")
client := bybit.NewBybitHttpClient("YOUR_API_KEY", "YOUR_API_SECRET", bybit.WithBaseURL(bybit.TESTNET))
params := map[string]interface{}{ "category": "option",
	"request": []map[string]interface{}{
		{
			"category":    "option",
			"symbol":      "BTC-10FEB23-24000-C",
			"orderType":   "Limit",
			"side":        "Buy",
			"qty":         "0.1",
			"price":       "5",
			"orderIv":     "0.1",
			"timeInForce": "GTC",
			"orderLinkId": "9b381bb1-401",
			"mmp":         false,
			"reduceOnly":  false,
		},
		{
			"category":    "option",
			"symbol":      "BTC-10FEB23-24000-C",
			"orderType":   "Limit",
			"side":        "Buy",
			"qty":         "0.1",
			"price":       "5",
			"orderIv":     "0.1",
			"timeInForce": "GTC",
			"orderLinkId": "82ee86dd-001",
			"mmp":         false,
			"reduceOnly":  false,
		},
	},
}
client.NewUtaBybitServiceWithParams(params).PlaceBatchOrder(context.Background())
```

TITLE: Placing Market Order Using .NET SDK
DESCRIPTION: This .NET/C# snippet uses the Bybit.NET API trade service to place a linear market order. The trade service is initialized with API key and secret. The PlaceOrder method is invoked asynchronously with parameters defining category (linear), symbol (BLZUSDT), side (buy), order type (market), quantity, and time in force (GTC). The result is printed to the console. This snippet depends on the bybit.net.api SDK and async programming paradigms.

CODE:
```
using bybit.net.api.ApiServiceImp;
using bybit.net.api.Models.Trade;

var orderInfo = await tradeService.PlaceOrder(category: Category.LINEAR, symbol: "BLZUSDT", side: Side.BUY, orderType: OrderType.MARKET, qty: "15", timeInForce: TimeInForce.GTC);
Console.WriteLine(orderInfo);
```

TITLE: Node.js: Modify Master API Key
DESCRIPTION: This Node.js snippet utilizes the `bybit-api` library to update a master API key.  It initializes a `RestClientV5` instance, sets testnet mode, and calls the `updateMasterApiKey` method.  It then passes the desired IP restrictions and permissions.  The code also includes error handling with `catch` to log errors to the console.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/user/modify-master-apikey.mdx#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: n4js
CODE:
```
const { RestClientV5 } = require('bybit-api');

const client = new RestClientV5({
  testnet: true,
  key: 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx',
  secret: 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx',
});

client
  .updateMasterApiKey({
    ips: ['*'],
    permissions: {
      ContractTrade: ['Order', 'Position'],
      Spot: ['SpotTrade'],
      Wallet: ['AccountTransfer', 'SubMemberTransfer'],
      Options: ['OptionsTrade'],
      Derivatives: ['DerivativesTrade'],
      CopyTrading: ['CopyTrading'],
      BlockTrade: [],
      Exchange: ['ExchangeHistory'],
      NFT: ['NFTQueryProductList'],
    },
  })
  .then((response) => {
    console.log(response);
  })
  .catch((error) => {
    console.error(error);
  });
```

TITLE: Updating Subaccount API Key - Bybit Official Node.js SDK
DESCRIPTION: This Node.js snippet utilizes the official bybit-api Node.js SDK (RestClientV5) to update a subaccount API key. It initializes the API client with necessary credentials and calls updateSubApiKey with options for permissions, readOnly flag, and IP binding. Requires the bybit-api npm package. Outputs the SDK's response as a JavaScript object to the console, with error handling via promise catch. Parameters and usage should mirror those in the HTTP REST API; ensure to manage the 'testnet' and credential values appropriately.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/i18n/zh-TW/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/v5/user/modify-sub-apikey.mdx#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
const { RestClientV5 } = require('bybit-api');

const client = new RestClientV5({
  testnet: true,
  key: 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx',
  secret: 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx',
});

client
  .updateSubApiKey({
    readOnly: 0,
    ips: ['*'],
    permissions: {
      ContractTrade: [],
      Spot: ['SpotTrade'],
      Wallet: ['AccountTransfer'],
      Options: [],
      Derivatives: [],
      CopyTrading: [],
      BlockTrade: [],
      Exchange: [],
      NFT: [],
    },
  })
  .then((response) => {
    console.log(response);
  })
  .catch((error) => {
    console.error(error);
  });
```

SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/i18n/zh-TW/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/v5/otc/repay-info.mdx#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
const { RestClientV5 } = require('bybit-api');

const client = new RestClientV5({
  testnet: true,
  key: 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx',
  secret: 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx',
});

client
  .getInstitutionalLendingRepayOrders({
    limit: 100,
  })
  .then((response) => {
    console.log(response);
  })
  .catch((error) => {
    console.error(error);
  });
```

TITLE: Subscribing to Linear Market Ticker Stream using Python WebSocket API
DESCRIPTION: Establishes a WebSocket connection to Bybit's testnet for Linear market ticker data. The script creates a connection, sets up a message handler, subscribes to BTCUSDT ticker updates, and maintains the connection with a sleep loop.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/websocket/public/ticker.mdx#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from pybit.unified_trading import WebSocket
from time import sleep
ws = WebSocket(
    testnet=True,
    channel_type="linear",
)
def handle_message(message):
    print(message)
ws.ticker_stream(
    symbol="BTCUSDT",
    callback=handle_message
)
while True:
    sleep(1)
```

TITLE: Setting TP/SL Mode using bybit-api npm Package - Node.js
DESCRIPTION: This Node.js snippet shows how to set the TP/SL mode using the 'bybit-api' npm package. It initializes the REST client with testnet enabled and authenticates with an API key and secret. The 'setTPSLMode' function is called with the necessary parameters: symbol, category, and tpSlMode. It handles both successful responses and errors via promises. Dependencies include Node.js and the 'bybit-api' package. Input parameters are symbol (e.g., 'XRPUSDT'), category, and tpSlMode; the output is the resolved API response.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/position/tpsl-mode.mdx#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: n4js
CODE:
```
const { RestClientV5 } = require('bybit-api');

const client = new RestClientV5({
    testnet: true,
    key: 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx',
    secret: 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx',
});

client
    .setTPSLMode({
        symbol: 'XRPUSDT',
        category: 'linear',
        tpSlMode: 'Full',
    })
    .then((response) => {
        console.log(response);
    })
    .catch((error) => {
        console.error(error);
    });
```

TITLE: Batch Cancel Orders Using pybit Unified Trading HTTP Client in Python
DESCRIPTION: This Python snippet shows how to use the pybit unified_trading HTTP client to batch cancel orders. It initializes an authenticated session with API key and secret for testnet, then calls cancel_batch_order with the product category and an array of order details specifying symbol and either orderId or orderLinkId. The method returns the response from the Bybit API confirming the cancellation requests, fitting scenarios where batch management of spot orders is required.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/i18n/zh-TW/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/v5/order/batch-cancel.mdx#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: Python
CODE:
```
from pybit.unified_trading import HTTP
session = HTTP(
    testnet=True,
    api_key="xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx",
    api_secret="xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx",
)
print(session.cancel_batch_order(
    category="spot",
    request=[
        {
            "symbol": "BTCUSDT",
            "orderId": "1666800494330512128"
        },
        {
            "symbol": "ATOMUSDT",
            "orderLinkId": "1666800494330512129"
        }
    ]
))
```

TITLE: Retrieving Historical Option Volatility Data with Go

TITLE: Setting Trading Stop with Java
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to set a take profit and stop loss order using the Bybit Java API client. It creates a new asynchronous position REST client, builds a `PositionDataRequest` object with the order parameters, and calls the `setTradingStop` method. This snippet requires the `bybit-api-client` dependency.  It sets category, symbol, takeProfit, stopLoss, tpTriggerBy, slTriggerBy, tpslMode, tpOrderType, slOrderType, tpSize, slSize, tpLimitPrice, slLimitPrice
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/i18n/zh-TW/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/v5/position/trading-stop.mdx#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: java
CODE:
```
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.position.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.position.request.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.service.BybitApiClientFactory;
var client = BybitApiClientFactory.newInstance().newAsyncPositionRestClient();
var setTradingStopRequest = PositionDataRequest.builder().category(CategoryType.LINEAR).symbol("XRPUSDT").takeProfit("0.6").stopLoss("0.2").tpTriggerBy(TriggerBy.MARK_PRICE).slTriggerBy(TriggerBy.LAST_PRICE)
                .tpslMode(TpslMode.PARTIAL).tpOrderType(TradeOrderType.LIMIT).slOrderType(TradeOrderType.LIMIT).tpSize("50").slSize("50").tpLimitPrice("0.57").slLimitPrice("0.21").build();
client.setTradingStop(setTradingStopRequest, System.out::println);
```

DESCRIPTION: This Javascript snippet demonstrates how to send a `ping` heartbeat packet to the Bybit WebSocket server. LANGUAGE: Javascript
CODE:
```
// req_id is a customised ID, which is optional
ws.send(JSON.stringify({"req_id": "100001", "op": "ping"}));
```

TITLE: Setting Auto Add Margin - Java
DESCRIPTION: This Java snippet demonstrates setting auto-add-margin using the Bybit API client. It imports necessary classes for building the request and interacting with the API. TITLE: Subscribing to Orderbook Stream using Python
DESCRIPTION: This Python snippet demonstrates how to connect to the Bybit WebSocket API using the pybit library and subscribe to the orderbook stream for a specific symbol and depth. It sets up a callback function to handle incoming messages and keeps the script running to receive updates.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/websocket/public/orderbook.mdx#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from pybit.unified_trading import WebSocket
from time import sleep
ws = WebSocket(
    testnet=True,
    channel_type="linear",
)
def handle_message(message):
    print(message)
ws.orderbook_stream(
    depth=50,
    symbol="BTCUSDT",
    callback=handle_message
)
while True:
    sleep(1)
```

TITLE: Authenticated POST HTTP Request Example - Bybit Pay - HTTP
DESCRIPTION: This HTTP snippet demonstrates an authenticated POST request to Bybit Pay's REST API, including the necessary headers and JSON body. Required headers: X-BAPI-SIGN (computed signature), X-BAPI-API-KEY, X-BAPI-TIMESTAMP, X-BAPI-RECV-WINDOW, and Content-Type (application/json). Request body must be a valid JSON string matching the signature generation input. Adjust example values to match your actual API credentials, timestamp, and payload. Accurate formation of these headers and the body is mandatory for successful authentication.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/bybit-pay/guide.mdx#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: http
CODE:
```
POST /v5/order/create HTTP/1.1
Host: api-testnet.bybit.com
-H 'X-BAPI-SIGN: XXXXXXXXXX' \
-H 'X-BAPI-API-KEY: xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx' \
-H 'X-BAPI-TIMESTAMP: 1658385589135' \
-H 'X-BAPI-RECV-WINDOW: 5000' \
-H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
-d '{
"category": "option"
}'
```

TITLE: Setting TP/SL Mode using Bybit API Java Client - Java
DESCRIPTION: This Java snippet utilizes Bybit's Java API client libraries to set the TP/SL mode for a given symbol. It creates a new asynchronous REST client, builds a position data request with the symbol, category (e.g., 'LINEAR'), and tpslMode ('PARTIAL' or 'FULL'), and sends the request. The callback prints the response. Dependencies include Bybit's Java SDK and proper API key configuration. Inputs are the symbol, category, and tpslMode; the output is the asynchronous API response.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/position/tpsl-mode.mdx#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: java
CODE:
```
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.position.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.position.request.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.service.BybitApiClientFactory;
var client = BybitApiClientFactory.newInstance().newAsyncPositionRestClient();
var setTpSlRequest = PositionDataRequest.builder().category(CategoryType.LINEAR).symbol("BTCUSDT").tpslMode(TpslMode.PARTIAL).build();
client.swithMarginRequest(setTpSlRequest, System.out::println);
```

TITLE: Amending Orders with .Net
DESCRIPTION: This .Net example uses the `bybit.net.api` library to amend a batch of orders. It creates two `OrderRequest` objects, each specifying a symbol, order ID, quantity, and price. It then calls the `TradeService.AmendBatchOrder` method, passing the category and a list containing the two order requests.

```
using bybit.net.api.ApiServiceImp;

var order2 = new OrderRequest { Symbol = "BLZUSDT", OrderId = "xxxxxxxxxx", Qty = "15", Price = "0.6090" };
var orderInfoString = await TradeService.AmendBatchOrder(category:Category.LINEAR, request: new List<OrderRequest> { order1, order2 });
Console.WriteLine(orderInfoString);
```

TITLE: Query Mark Price Kline - Java

TITLE: Canceling All Linear Orders by Base Coin (Java)
DESCRIPTION: Utilizes the `com.bybit.api.client` library to cancel all linear orders using `baseCoin` ('USDT') via the Bybit API. It involves creating an `BybitApiClientFactory` with credentials, obtaining an async trade client (`BybitApiAsyncTradeRestClient`), building a `TradeOrderRequest` specifying the `category` (LINEAR) and `baseCoin`, and executing the `cancelAllOrder` method asynchronously.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/order/cancel-all.mdx#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: java
CODE:
```
import com.bybit.api.client.restApi.BybitApiTradeRestClient;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.trade.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.service.BybitApiClientFactory;
BybitApiClientFactory factory = BybitApiClientFactory.newInstance("YOUR_API_KEY", "YOUR_API_SECRET");
BybitApiAsyncTradeRestClient client = factory.newAsyncTradeRestClient();
var cancelAllOrdersRequest = TradeOrderRequest.builder().category(ProductType.LINEAR).baseCoin("USDT").build();
client.cancelAllOrder(cancelAllOrdersRequest, System.out::println);
```

TITLE: Creating Linear Limit Order with Go SDK
DESCRIPTION: This Go snippet shows how to instantiate a Bybit client using an external Go SDK and submit a limit order for a linear perpetual contract. The client is configured with API credentials and testnet base URL. The order parameters include category (linear), symbol, side (buy), position index, order type, quantity, price, and time in force. The PlaceOrder operation is executed in a Go context. The snippet assumes importing the official bybit.go.api client package and standard libraries.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/order/create-order.mdx#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: go
CODE:
```
import (
    "context"
	"fmt"
	bybit "https://github.com/bybit-exchange/bybit.go.api")
client := bybit.NewBybitHttpClient("YOUR_API_KEY", "YOUR_API_SECRET", bybit.WithBaseURL(bybit.TESTNET))
params := map[string]interface{}{
		"category":    "linear",
		"symbol":      "BTCUSDT",
		"side":        "Buy",
		"positionIdx": 0,
		"orderType":   "Limit",
		"qty":         "0.001",
		"price":       "10000",
		"timeInForce": "GTC",
	}
client.NewUtaBybitServiceWithParams(params).PlaceOrder(context.Background())
```

TITLE: Generating Signature String for POST Request - Bybit Pay - Shell
DESCRIPTION: This shell snippet demonstrates how to create the plaintext string for signing POST requests to Bybit Pay's REST API. The plaintext is formed by directly concatenating the timestamp, API key, receive window, and the raw JSON request body. Required fields include timestamp (numeric, ms), api_key (your API key), recv_window, and the exact JSON body as a compact string. The resulting string should be signed with either HMAC_SHA256 or RSA_SHA256, corresponding to your API key type. Incorrect formatting or omission of fields will prevent successful authentication.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/bybit-pay/guide.mdx#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: shell
CODE:
```
# rule:
timestamp+api_key+recv_window+raw_request_body

# param_str
1658385579423XXXXXXXXXX5000{
"category": "option"
}

# parse
timestamp = 1658385579423
api_key = XXXXXXXXXX
recv_window = 5000
raw_request_body = {"category": "option"}
```

TITLE: Subscribe to Position Stream - Python
DESCRIPTION: This Python code snippet shows how to subscribe to the position stream using the `pybit` library. It initializes a WebSocket connection to Bybit's unified trading API, sets up a callback function to handle incoming messages, and then subscribes to the position stream. It requires the `pybit` library and valid API keys and secrets.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/i18n/zh-TW/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/v5/websocket/private/position.mdx#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from pybit.unified_trading import WebSocket
from time import sleep
ws = WebSocket(
    testnet=True,
    channel_type="private",
    api_key="xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx",
    api_secret="xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx",
)
def handle_message(message):
    print(message)
ws.position_stream(callback=handle_message)
while True:
    sleep(1)
```

TITLE: HTTP Request for Updating Master API Key on Bybit
DESCRIPTION: An example of constructing a POST request to the /v5/user/update-api endpoint to modify the master API key permissions and IP bindings. Includes headers for authentication and a JSON body with optional parameters such as readOnly, ips, and permissions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/i18n/zh-TW/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/v5/user/modify-master-apikey.mdx#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: http
CODE:
```
POST /v5/user/update-api HTTP/1.1
Host: api.bybit.com
X-BAPI-API-KEY: xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
X-BAPI-TIMESTAMP: 1676431264739
X-BAPI-RECV-WINDOW: 5000
X-BAPI-SIGN: XXXXXX
Content-Type: application/json

{
    "readOnly": null,
    "ips": "*",
    "permissions": {
            "ContractTrade": [
                "Order",
                "Position"
            ],
            "Spot": [
                "SpotTrade"
            ],
            "Wallet": [
                "AccountTransfer",
                "SubMemberTransfer"
            ],
            "Options": [
                "OptionsTrade"
            ],
            "CopyTrading": [
                "CopyTrading"
            ],
            "BlockTrade": [],
            "Exchange": [
                "ExchangeHistory"
            ],
            "NFT": [
                "NFTQueryProductList"
            ]
        }
}
```

TITLE: Node.js SDK request to switch position mode on Bybit API
DESCRIPTION: This Node.js example uses the bybit-api package's RestClientV5 to call switchPositionMode with parameters such as category, symbol, and mode. It demonstrates asynchronous handling of the response and error catching for a seamless integration within a JavaScript environment.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/position/position-mode.mdx#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: n4js
CODE:
```
const { RestClientV5 } = require('bybit-api');

const client = new RestClientV5({
    testnet: true,
    key: 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx',
    secret: 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx',
});

client
    .switchPositionMode({
        category: 'inverse',
        symbol: 'BTCUSDH23',
        mode: 0,
    })
    .then((response) => {
        console.log(response);
    })
    .catch((error) => {
        console.error(error);
    });
```

TITLE: Querying Risk Limit Using Bybit Java SDK - Java
DESCRIPTION: Utilizes Bybit's Java SDK to asynchronously request risk limit information for the INVERSE category and symbol ADAUSD. Requires the com.bybit.api.client Java library. A MarketDataRequest is constructed with specified category and symbol, then submitted using the getRiskLimit method. The API response is handled asynchronously via a callback (here, System.out::println).
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/i18n/zh-TW/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/v5/market/risk-limit.mdx#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: java
CODE:
```
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.CategoryType;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.market.request.MarketDataRequest;
import com.bybit.api.client.service.BybitApiClientFactory;
var client = BybitApiClientFactory.newInstance().newAsyncMarketDataRestClient();
var riskMimitRequest = MarketDataRequest.builder().category(CategoryType.INVERSE).symbol("ADAUSD").build();
client.getRiskLimit(riskMimitRequest, System.out::println);
```

TITLE: Canceling Order - Java
DESCRIPTION: This Java code demonstrates canceling an order using the Bybit API client. It requires the Bybit API client library. It creates a BybitApiClientFactory and uses it to create an async trade rest client.  The code then calls the cancelOrder with a TradeOrderRequest object.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/order/cancel-order.mdx#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: java
CODE:
```
import com.bybit.api.client.restApi.BybitApiTradeRestClient;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.trade.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.service.BybitApiClientFactory;
BybitApiClientFactory factory = BybitApiClientFactory.newInstance("YOUR_API_KEY", "YOUR_API_SECRET");
BybitApiAsyncTradeRestClient client = factory.newAsyncTradeRestClient();
var cancelOrderRequest = TradeOrderRequest.builder().category(ProductType.SPOT).symbol("XRPUSDT").orderId("1523347543495541248").build();
var canceledOrder = client.cancelOrder(cancelOrderRequest);
System.out.println(canceledOrder);
```

TITLE: Subscribing to Orderbook Depth Data with Python in Bybit Exchange
DESCRIPTION: This Python example demonstrates how to subscribe to the orderbook stream for BTCUSDT with a depth of 50 levels using the pybit library. It initializes a WebSocket connection to the Bybit testnet for linear trading and sets up a callback function to handle incoming messages.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/i18n/zh-TW/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/v5/websocket/public/orderbook.mdx#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from pybit.unified_trading import WebSocket
from time import sleep
ws = WebSocket(
    testnet=True,
    channel_type="linear",
)
def handle_message(message):
    print(message)
ws.orderbook_stream(
    depth=50,
    symbol="BTCUSDT",
    callback=handle_message
)
while True:
    sleep(1)
```

TITLE: Querying Open Interest in GO
DESCRIPTION: This Go code uses the `bybit.go.api` library to retrieve open interest data from the Bybit API. It sets up a Bybit HTTP client and defines parameters for category and symbol.  It calls `GetOpenInterests` to fetch data from the testnet.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/market/open-interest.mdx#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: go
CODE:
```
import (
	"context"
	"fmt"
	bybit "github.com/wuhewuhe/bybit.go.api"
)
client := bybit.NewBybitHttpClient("", "", bybit.WithBaseURL(bybit.TESTNET))
params := map[string]interface{}{"category": "linear", "symbol": "BTCUSDT"}
client.NewUtaBybitServiceWithParams(params).GetOpenInterests(context.Background())
```

TITLE: Switch Margin Mode Java
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to switch the margin mode using the Bybit API client in Java. It initializes an asynchronous position REST client, creates a `PositionDataRequest` object with the required parameters, and then calls the `swithMarginRequest` method to switch the margin mode. It requires the Bybit API client library.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/position/cross-isolate.mdx#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: java
CODE:
```
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.position.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.position.request.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.service.BybitApiClientFactory;
var client = BybitApiClientFactory.newInstance().newAsyncPositionRestClient();
var switchMarginRequest = PositionDataRequest.builder().category(CategoryType.LINEAR).symbol("BTC-31MAR23").tradeMode(MarginMode.CROSS_MARGIN).buyLeverage("5").sellLeverage("5").build();
client.swithMarginRequest(switchMarginRequest, System.out::println);
```

TITLE: Subscribing to Order Stream with pybit (Python)
DESCRIPTION: This Python script uses the `pybit` library to connect to the Bybit private WebSocket channel and subscribe to the order stream. It requires API credentials (key and secret) and defines a callback function `handle_message` to process incoming order update messages.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/websocket/private/order.mdx#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from pybit.unified_trading import WebSocket
from time import sleep
ws = WebSocket(
    testnet=True,
    channel_type="private",
    api_key="xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx",
    api_secret="xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx",
)
def handle_message(message):
    print(message)
ws.order_stream(callback=handle_message)
while True:
    sleep(1)
```

TITLE: Moving Positions Using Bybit Java SDK
DESCRIPTION: This Java code demonstrates how to use the Bybit Java SDK to initiate a batch position move between two UIDs. It involves creating `MovePositionDetailsRequest` objects for each position (e.g., SPOT BTCUSDT and ETHUSDT) and adding them to a `BatchMovePositionRequest`. The request specifies the `fromUid`, `toUid`, and the list of position details. Finally, it calls the asynchronous `batchMovePositions` method on the `AsyncPositionRestClient`. Requires the `com.bybit.api.client` library.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/position/move-position.mdx#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: java
CODE:
```
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.position.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.position.request.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.service.BybitApiClientFactory;
var client = BybitApiClientFactory.newInstance().newAsyncPositionRestClient();
var movePositionsRequest = Arrays.asList(MovePositionDetailsRequest.builder().category(CategoryType.SPOT.getCategoryTypeId()).symbol("BTCUSDT").side(Side.SELL.getTransactionSide()).price("100").qty("0.01").build(),
                MovePositionDetailsRequest.builder().category(CategoryType.SPOT.getCategoryTypeId()).symbol("ETHUSDT").side(Side.SELL.getTransactionSide()).price("100").qty("0.01").build());
var batchMovePositionsRequest = BatchMovePositionRequest.builder().fromUid("123456").toUid("456789").list(movePositionsRequest).build();
System.out.println(client.batchMovePositions(batchMovePositionsRequest));
```

TITLE: Subscribing to K-line Data with WebSocket Python
DESCRIPTION: This Python code snippet demonstrates how to subscribe to K-line data using the `pybit` library's WebSocket functionality. The script uses the `pybit.unified_trading` library and requires an active internet connection to the Bybit API.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/i18n/zh-TW/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/v5/websocket/public/kline.mdx#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from pybit.unified_trading import WebSocket
from time import sleep
ws = WebSocket(
    testnet=True,
    channel_type="linear",
)
def handle_message(message):
    print(message)
ws.kline_stream(
    interval=5,
    symbol="BTCUSDT",
    callback=handle_message
)
while True:
    sleep(1)
```

TITLE: Node.js Example for Retrieving Open Interest
DESCRIPTION: This JavaScript snippet uses the 'bybit-api' package to instantiate a REST client configured for the testnet, then calls getOpenInterest with specified parameters like category, symbol, intervalTime, startTime, and endTime. The response is logged to the console upon success.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/i18n/zh-TW/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/v5/market/open-interest.mdx#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: Node.js
CODE:
```
const { RestClientV5 } = require('bybit-api');

const client = new RestClientV5({
    testnet: true,
});

client
    .getOpenInterest({
        category: 'inverse',
        symbol: 'BTCUSD',
        intervalTime: '5min',
        startTime: 1669571100000,
        endTime: 1669571400000,
    })
    .then((response) => {
        console.log(response);

It initializes the API client with testnet, API key, and API secret, then calls the `get_chat_messages` method, passing the order ID and page size as arguments.  It demonstrates a simple API call to fetch chat messages.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/p2p/order/chat-msg.mdx#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from bybit_p2p import P2P
api = P2P(
    testnet=True,
    api_key="xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx",
    api_secret="xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx"
)
print(api.get_chat_messages(
    orderId="1898976123321221120",
    size=1
))
```

TITLE: Asynchronous Batch Order Placement with Bybit .Net SDK
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to place batch orders using Bybit's .Net API client by creating individual OrderRequest objects with parameters such as symbol, order type, side, quantity, price, and time in force. These orders are added to a list and submitted asynchronously through the TradeService's PlaceBatchOrder method specifying the category (e.g., linear contracts). The method returns a string detailing the order info. The snippet requires importing Bybit .Net API namespaces and appropriate asynchronous programming support in C#.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/order/batch-place.mdx#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: c#
CODE:
```
using bybit.net.api.ApiServiceImp;
using bybit.net.api.Models.Trade;
var order1 = new OrderRequest { Symbol = "XRPUSDT", OrderType = "Limit", Side = "Buy", Qty = "10", Price = "0.6080", TimeInForce = "GTC" };
var order2 = new OrderRequest { Symbol = "BLZUSDT", OrderType = "Limit", Side = "Buy", Qty = "10", Price = "0.6080", TimeInForce = "GTC" };
List<OrderRequest> request = new() { order1, order2 };
var orderInfoString = await TradeService.PlaceBatchOrder(category: Category.LINEAR, request: request);
Console.WriteLine(orderInfoString);
```

TITLE: Submitting Market and Limit Orders Using Node.js SDK
DESCRIPTION: This Node.js snippet demonstrates usage of the official Bybit RestClientV5 SDK to submit market and limit orders. The client is instantiated with testnet enabled and API credentials. The submitOrder method sends requests with payloads specifying order category (spot), symbol, side, order type, quantity, and optional price for limit orders. Responses and errors are handled using promises with then/catch blocks, printing results or errors to the console. This example covers basic order submissions with asynchronous JavaScript code using the Bybit SDK.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/order/create-order.mdx#_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: n4js
CODE:
```
const { RestClientV5 } = require('bybit-api');

const client = new RestClientV5({
  testnet: true,
  key: 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx',
  secret: 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx',
});

// Submit a market order
client
  .submitOrder({
    category: 'spot',
    symbol: 'BTCUSDT',
    side: 'Buy',
    orderType: 'Market',
    qty: '1',
  })
  .then((response) => {
    console.log('Market order result', response);
  })
  .catch((error) => {
    console.error('Market order error', error);
  });

// Submit a limit order
client
  .submitOrder({
    category: 'spot',
    symbol: 'BTCUSDT',
    side: 'Buy',
    orderType: 'Limit',
    qty: '1',
    price: '55000',
  })
  .then((response) => {
    console.log('Limit order result', response);
  })
  .catch((error) => {
    console.error('Limit order error', error);
  });
```

CODE:

import com.bybit.api.client.domain.*;

import com.bybit.api.client.domain.position.request.*;

TITLE: Amend Order with Java
DESCRIPTION: This Java code snippet demonstrates how to amend an order using the Bybit API client. It initializes the client with API keys and secret, creates an `TradeOrderRequest` object with the new parameters, and then calls the `amendOrder` method. Requires the `com.bybit.api.client` library.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/order/amend-order.mdx#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: java
CODE:
```
import com.bybit.api.client.restApi.BybitApiTradeRestClient;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.trade.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.service.BybitApiClientFactory;
BybitApiClientFactory factory = BybitApiClientFactory.newInstance("YOUR_API_KEY", "YOUR_API_SECRET");
BybitApiAsyncTradeRestClient client = factory.newAsyncTradeRestClient();
var amendOrderRequest = TradeOrderRequest.builder().orderId("1523347543495541248").category(ProductType.LINEAR).symbol("XRPUSDT")
                        .price("0.5")  // setting a new price, for example
                        .qty("15")  // and a new quantity
                        .build();
var amendedOrder = client.amendOrder(amendOrderRequest);
System.out.println(amendedOrder);
```

TITLE: Retrieving Classic Transaction Logs Using Bybit API Node.js SDK
DESCRIPTION: This JavaScript snippet uses the Bybit API SDK (RestClientV5) to query the classic account transaction logs programmatically. It initializes the client with API credentials for the Bybit testnet environment, then calls `getClassicTransactionLogs` with parameters to limit results to one entry for the BTCUSD symbol. It handles the returned Promise to log the response or catch and log errors. This requires the 'bybit-api' package and valid API key and secret. Inputs include query parameters such as limit and symbol; output is a JSON-structured transaction log response.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/account/contract-transaction-log.mdx#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: n4js
CODE:
```
const { RestClientV5 } = require('bybit-api');

const client = new RestClientV5({
  testnet: true,
  key: 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx',
  secret: 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx',
});

client
  .getClassicTransactionLogs({
    limit: 1,
    symbol: 'BTCUSD',
  })
  .then((response) => {
    console.log(response);
  })
  .catch((error) => {
    console.error(error);
  });
```

TITLE: Batch Order Submission Using Bybit Java SDK
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates creating batch options orders asynchronously via the Bybit Java API client library. The snippet imports necessary domain and service classes, initializes a client factory with API keys, and builds a list of trade order requests using the builder pattern. It specifies per-order parameters such as product type, symbol, side, order type, quantity, price, implied volatility, time in force, order link ID, and order flags. The 'createBatchOrder' method submits the batch to Bybit, with results handled using a lambda printing output to system console. The examples require Bybit Java SDK dependencies configured in the project.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/order/batch-place.mdx#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: java
CODE:
```
import com.bybit.api.client.restApi.BybitApiAsyncTradeRestClient;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.ProductType;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.TradeOrderType;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.trade.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.service.BybitApiClientFactory;
import java.util.Arrays;
BybitApiClientFactory factory = BybitApiClientFactory.newInstance("YOUR_API_KEY", "YOUR_API_SECRET");
BybitApiAsyncTradeRestClient client = factory.newAsyncTradeRestClient();
var orderRequests = Arrays.asList(TradeOrderRequest.builder().category(ProductType.OPTION).symbol("BTC-10FEB23-24000-C").side(Side.BUY).orderType(TradeOrderType.LIMIT).qty("0.1")
                        .price("5").orderIv("0.1").timeInForce(TimeInForce.GOOD_TILL_CANCEL).orderLinkId("9b381bb1-401").mmp(false).reduceOnly(false).build(),
                TradeOrderRequest.builder().category(ProductType.OPTION).symbol("BTC-10FEB23-24000-C").side(Side.BUY).orderType(TradeOrderType.LIMIT).qty("0.1")
                        .price("5").orderIv("0.1").timeInForce(TimeInForce.GOOD_TILL_CANCEL).orderLinkId("82ee86dd-001").mmp(false).reduceOnly(false).build());
var createBatchOrders = BatchOrderRequest.builder().category(ProductType.OPTION).request(orderRequests).build();
client.createBatchOrder(createBatchOrders, System.out::println);
```

TITLE: Getting Long Short Ratio with Bybit API in Java
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to retrieve the market account ratio using the Bybit API in Java. It requires the `com.bybit.api.client` dependency. The code initializes a Bybit API client, constructs a MarketDataRequest with the specified parameters (category, symbol, data recording period, and limit), and then asynchronously calls the getMarketAccountRatio method.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/market/long-short-ratio.mdx#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: java
CODE:
```
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.CategoryType;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.market.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.market.request.MarketDataRequest;
import com.bybit.api.client.service.BybitApiClientFactory;
var client = BybitApiClientFactory.newInstance().newAsyncMarketDataRestClient();
var marketAccountRatioRequest = MarketDataRequest.builder().category(CategoryType.LINEAR).symbol("BTCUSDT").dataRecordingPeriod(DataRecordingPeriod.FIFTEEN_MINUTES).limit(10).build();
client.getMarketAccountRatio(marketAccountRatioRequest, System.out::println);
```

TITLE: Subscribing to Leveraged Token Kline Stream in Python
DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to subscribe to the leveraged token kline WebSocket stream using the pybit library. It creates a WebSocket connection to the testnet, sets up a callback function to handle incoming messages, and subscribes to 30-minute interval kline data for the EOS3LUSDT leveraged token.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/websocket/public/etp-kline.mdx#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from pybit.unified_trading import WebSocket
from time import sleep
ws = WebSocket(
    testnet=True,
    channel_type="spot",
)
def handle_message(message):
    print(message)
ws.lt_kline_stream(
    interval=30,
    symbol="EOS3LUSDT",
    callback=handle_message
)
while True:
    sleep(1)
```

TITLE: Generating Signature Plain Text for HTTP POST Requests with HMAC/RSA in Shell
DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates constructing the plain text string to be signed when making POST requests to Bybit APIs. The format is a concatenation of the timestamp, API key, receive window, and the raw JSON request body. This resultant string is then signed using HMAC_SHA256 or RSA_SHA256 algorithms to produce the authentication signature. Prerequisites include a valid API key, UTC timestamp, and the JSON payload to be sent as the POST request body.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v3/intro.mdx#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: shell
CODE:
```
# rule:
timestamp+api_key+recv_window+raw_request_body

# param_str
1658385579423XXXXXXXXXX5000{
    "category": "linear"
}

# parse
timestamp = 1658385579423
api_key = XXXXXXXXXX
recv_window = 5000
raw_request_body = {"category": "linear"}
```

TITLE: Generating API Signature HMAC SHA256
DESCRIPTION: This shell snippet demonstrates the rule used to generate a plain text for HMAC-SHA256 encryption, which is required for signing GET requests to the Bybit API.  It lists the required parameters and how they're formatted before being signed. Dependencies are the API key, timestamp, recv_window and the query string.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/guide.mdx#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: shell
CODE:
```
# rule:
timestamp+api_key+recv_window+queryString

# example values:
timestamp = "1658384314791"
api_key = "XXXXXXXXXX"
recv_window = "5000"
queryString = "category=option&symbol=BTC-29JUL22-25000-C"

# resulting string that needs to be signed:
"1658384314791XXXXXXXXXX5000category=option&symbol=BTC-29JUL22-25000-C"

# resulting example signature for HMAC:
"410e0f387bafb7afd0f1722c068515e09945610124fa11774da1da857b72f30b"
```

TITLE: Subscribing to Option Market Ticker Stream using Python WebSocket API
DESCRIPTION: Establishes a WebSocket connection to Bybit's testnet for Option market ticker data. The script connects to the option channel, registers a callback function, and subscribes to a specific BTC option contract's ticker updates.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/websocket/public/ticker.mdx#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from pybit.unified_trading import WebSocket
from time import sleep
ws = WebSocket(
    testnet=True,
    channel_type="option",
)
def handle_message(message):
    print(message)
ws.ticker_stream(
    symbol="tickers.BTC-22JAN23-17500-C",
    callback=handle_message
)
while True:
    sleep(1)
```

}'

TITLE: Java SDK for Retrieving Inverse Market Tickers
DESCRIPTION: Creates a Java client session and constructs a MarketDataRequest for inverse category and BTCUSD symbol, then fetches and prints the market ticker data. Requires the bybit.api.client library.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/market/tickers.mdx#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: java
CODE:
```
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.CategoryType;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.market.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.market.request.MarketDataRequest;
import com.bybit.api.client.service.BybitApiClientFactory;
var client = BybitApiClientFactory.newInstance().newAsyncMarketDataRestClient();
var tickerRequest = MarketDataRequest.builder().category(CategoryType.INVERSE).symbol("BTCUSD").build();
client.getMarketTickers(tickerRequest, System.out::println);
```

TITLE: Constructing POST Request Signature
DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates how to construct the plaintext string for signing a POST request to the Bybit API. It includes the timestamp, API key, receive window, and the raw request body. The plaintext is then used to generate the signature using HMAC_SHA256 or RSA_SHA256.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/i18n/zh-TW/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/v3/intro.mdx#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: shell
CODE:
```
# 拼接規則:
timestamp+api_key+recv_window+raw_request_body

# 明文
1658385579423XXXXXXXXXX5000{
"category": "option"
}

# 解析
timestamp = 1658385579423
api_key = XXXXXXXXXX
recv_window = 5000
raw_request_body = {"category": "option"}
```

TITLE: Subscribing to Bybit Trade Stream using Python
DESCRIPTION: This Python snippet demonstrates how to connect to the Bybit Unified Trading WebSocket (testnet) and subscribe to the public trade stream for a specific symbol ('BTCUSDT') using the 'pybit' library. It defines a callback function 'handle_message' to process incoming trade messages and keeps the connection open with an infinite loop.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/websocket/public/trade.mdx#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from pybit.unified_trading import WebSocket
from time import sleep
ws = WebSocket(
    testnet=True,
    channel_type="linear",
)
def handle_message(message):
    print(message)
ws.trade_stream(
    symbol="BTCUSDT",
    callback=handle_message
)
while True:
    sleep(1)
```

TITLE: Executing Bybit UTA Upgrade in Java
DESCRIPTION: This Java snippet uses the Bybit API Client library to perform the Unified Trading Account upgrade. It initializes a client factory with the API key, secret, and testnet domain. It then obtains the account rest client and calls the `upgradeAccountToUTA()` method to initiate the upgrade process.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/account/upgrade-unified-account.mdx#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: Java
CODE:
```
import com.bybit.api.client.config.BybitApiConfig;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.account.request.AccountDataRequest;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.account.AccountType;
import com.bybit.api.client.service.BybitApiClientFactory;
var client = BybitApiClientFactory.newInstance("YOUR_API_KEY", "YOUR_API_SECRET", BybitApiConfig.TESTNET_DOMAIN).newAccountRestClient();
System.out.println(client.upgradeAccountToUTA());
```

import com.bybit.api.client.domain.announcement.LanguageSymbol;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.market.request.MarketDataRequest;

TITLE: Querying Spot Instrument Info using Java
DESCRIPTION: This snippet retrieves spot instrument information using the Bybit API Java SDK.  It creates an asynchronous market data REST client, builds a `MarketDataRequest` with category set to SPOT, symbol, and other optional parameters, and then calls `getInstrumentsInfo` to fetch the data asynchronously. The result is printed to the console.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/market/instrument.mdx#_snippet_14

LANGUAGE: java
CODE:
```
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.market.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.market.request.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.service.BybitApiClientFactory;
var client = BybitApiClientFactory.newInstance().newAsyncMarketDataRestClient();
var instrumentInfoRequest = MarketDataRequest.builder().category(CategoryType.SPOT).symbol("BTCUSDT").instrumentStatus(InstrumentStatus.TRADING).limit(500).build();
client.getInstrumentsInfo(instrumentInfoRequest,System.out::println);
```

TITLE: Querying Coin Info using bybit-api (Node.js)
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates querying coin info using the `bybit-api` Node.js library. It creates a `RestClientV5` instance configured for the testnet with API credentials and calls the `getCoinInfo` method for 'MNT', handling the response asynchronously using promises.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/asset/coin-info.mdx#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
const { RestClientV5 } = require('bybit-api');

const client = new RestClientV5({
  testnet: true,
  key: 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx',
  secret: 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx',
});

client
  .getCoinInfo('MNT')
  .then((response) => {
    console.log(response);
  })
  .catch((error) => {
    console.error(error);
  });
```

TITLE: Java SDK request to switch position mode on Bybit API
DESCRIPTION: This Java example utilizes the Bybit API client to configure and send a request for switching position modes. It constructs a PositionDataRequest with specified category, symbol, and position mode, then executes the switchPositionMode method. This approach integrates API calls within a Java environment, providing detailed object construction.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/v5/position/position-mode.mdx#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: java

TITLE: Move Positions Java Example
DESCRIPTION: This Java example demonstrates how to use the Bybit API client to move positions. It creates a `BatchMovePositionRequest` object with the `fromUid`, `toUid`, and a list of `MovePositionDetailsRequest` objects. Each `MovePositionDetailsRequest` specifies the category, symbol, side, price, and quantity to move.  It requires the `com.bybit.api.client` library.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/i18n/zh-TW/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/v5/position/move-position.mdx#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: java
CODE:
```
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.position.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.position.request.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.service.BybitApiClientFactory;
var client = BybitApiClientFactory.newInstance().newAsyncPositionRestClient();
var movePositionsRequest = Arrays.asList(MovePositionDetailsRequest.builder().category(CategoryType.SPOT.getCategoryTypeId()).symbol("BTCUSDT").side(Side.SELL.getTransactionSide()).price("100").qty("0.01").build(),
                MovePositionDetailsRequest.builder().category(CategoryType.SPOT.getCategoryTypeId()).symbol("ETHUSDT").side(Side.SELL.getTransactionSide()).price("100").qty("0.01").build());
var batchMovePositionsRequest = BatchMovePositionRequest.builder().fromUid("123456").toUid("456789").list(movePositionsRequest).build();
System.out.println(client.batchMovePositions(batchMovePositionsRequest));
```

)

client.NewUtaBybitServiceWithParams(params).GetMarketRiskLimits(context.Background())

TITLE: Java: Setting TP/SL Mode on Bybit
DESCRIPTION: This Java snippet demonstrates setting the TP/SL mode for a position using the Bybit API client. It utilizes the BybitApiClientFactory and the PositionDataRequest to build the request. Required dependencies include the Bybit API client library and a configured Java environment. The code then calls the client.swithMarginRequest function to make the API request.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/i18n/zh-TW/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/v5/position/tpsl-mode.mdx#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: java
CODE:
```
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.position.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.domain.position.request.*;
import com.bybit.api.client.service.BybitApiClientFactory;
var client = BybitApiClientFactory.newInstance().newAsyncPositionRestClient();
var setTpSlRequest = PositionDataRequest.builder().category(CategoryType.LINEAR).symbol("BTCUSDT").tpslMode(TpslMode.PARTIAL).build();
client.swithMarginRequest(setTpSlRequest, System.out::println);
```

TITLE: Node.js: Setting TP/SL Mode on Bybit
DESCRIPTION: This Node.js snippet utilizes the bybit-api library to set the TP/SL mode. It instantiates a RestClientV5, setting the testnet environment and providing API keys. It then calls the setTPSLMode method, passing the symbol, category, and tpSlMode as parameters. The response, or any error, is then logged to the console.  Requires the bybit-api package installed.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/i18n/zh-TW/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/v5/position/tpsl-mode.mdx#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: node.js
CODE:
```
const { RestClientV5 } = require('bybit-api');

const client = new RestClientV5({
    testnet: true,
    key: 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx',
    secret: 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx',
});

client
    .setTPSLMode({
        symbol: 'XRPUSDT',
        category: 'linear',
        tpSlMode: 'Full',
    })
    .then((response) => {
        console.log(response);
    })
    .catch((error) => {
        console.error(error);
    });
```

TITLE: Send Chat Message Python
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates sending a chat message using the `bybit_p2p` Python library. It initializes the `P2P` class with API credentials and testnet flag. Then it calls the `send_chat_message` method with the message, content type, order ID, and a unique message UUID generated using `uuid.uuid4().hex`. The output is a dictionary containing the API response.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/docs/p2p/order/send-chat-msg.mdx#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from bybit_p2p import P2P
import uuid
api = P2P(
    testnet=True,
    api_key="xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx",
    api_secret="xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx"
)
print(api.send_chat_message(
    message="hi, test",
    contentType="str",
    orderId="1898976123321221120",
    msgUuid=uuid.uuid4().hex
))
```

TITLE: Querying Exchange Order Records (Node.js)
DESCRIPTION: Example using the `bybit-api` Node.js library to fetch coin exchange records. It creates an authenticated `RestClientV5` instance for the testnet and invokes `getCoinExchangeRecords` with a limit of 10, handling the response asynchronously. Requires the `bybit-api` package.
SOURCE: https://github.com/bybit-exchange/docs/blob/master/i18n/zh-TW/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/v5/asset/exchange.mdx#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: n4js
CODE:
```
const { RestClientV5 } = require('bybit-api');

const client = new RestClientV5({
  testnet: true,
  key: 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx',
  secret: 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx',
});

client
  .getCoinExchangeRecords({ limit: 10 })
  .then((response) => {
    console.log(response);
  })
  .catch((error) => {
    console.error(error);
  });
```
